newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan buys T$2b U.S. Stinger missile system - paper.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan buys T$2b U.S. Stinger missile system - paper.

text.p: Taiwan has signed a contract to buy an anti-aircraft missile system from the United States for about T$2 billion (US$72 million), the China Times reported on Thursday.
The system includes more than 700 Stinger missiles, the newspaper said. A defence ministry spokesman was not available immediately for comment.
Defence minister Chiang Chung-ling said in March Taiwan planned to buy Stinger missiles, but declined to give details of their price or how many would be bought.

Taiwan on Thursday commissioned two tank landing ships (LSTs) leased from the United States. The ministry said it had leased a total of six LSTs but did not say when the remaining four might arrive in Taiwan.
Separately, Taiwan has ordered six Lafayette-class missile frigates from France and taken delivery of two so far.
It is also paying T$15 million (US$590,000) each for 160 second-hand U.S. M60A3 tanks, all of which are more than 10 years old.
Taiwan maintains it needs advanced weapons to counter the rapid military modernisation of China, the island's arch rival since a civil war separated them in 1949.

China held war games and missile tests in the Taiwan Strait in the weeks before Taiwan's presidential election last year in what Beijing acknowledged was a bid to intimidate voters against pursuing independence.
Beijing vows to retake Taiwan by force if the island opts for independence.
